text: Bringing that lesson to bear here, the only way the operating system could protect against ransomware would be to raise “Are you sure?” dialog boxes on everyday operations against the kinds of files that ransomware targets.

text: As shoppers and retailers gear up for the 2017 holiday season, they need to be aware of a new kind of cybersecurity threat they may face this year: unauthorized coin mining.

text: Unauthorized coin mining is a new threat that can affect retailers and shoppers in a way that could impact or even halt their online shopping experience.

text: A recent Unit 42 threat intelligence posting on the topic showed how 63 percent of the unauthorized coin mining sites we found came online in October 2017.

text: This surge in unauthorized coin mining is driven, in large part, by the recent skyrocketing in the value of digital currencies like bitcoin.

text: As that trend shows no sign of slowing down anytime soon, we can expect this to remain a very lucrative avenue for attackers.

But because of the potential impact on holiday shopping and the ease of attacks, unauthorized coin mining is an attack that retailers need to be aware of and take active steps for prevention this holiday season.

text: The best way to understand the threat of unauthorized coin mining is to first understand its impact.

text: “Coin miner” code is code used to “mine” for digital currency like bitcoin.

text: One of the most important “innovations” in malware in the past decade is what’s called a Domain Generation Algorithm (“DGA”)”.

text: DGA is an automation technique that attackers use to make it harder for defenders to protect against attacks.

text: While DGA has been in use for over 10 years now, it’s still a potent technique that has been a particular challenge for defenders to counter.

text: What is it?
label: safe

text: A Domain Generation Algorithm is a program that is designed to generate domain names in a particular fashion.
label: safe
tokenize_text: domain generation algorithm program designed generate domain name particular fashion

text: Attackers developed DGAs so that malware can quickly generate a list of domains that it can use for the sites that give it instructions and receive information from the malware (usually referred to as “command and control” or C2).
label: safe

text: Attackers use DGA so that they can quickly switch the domains that they’re using for the malware attacks.
label: safe

text: Attackers do this because security software and vendors act quickly to block and take down malicious domains that malware uses.
label: safe

text: Attackers developed DGA specifically to counter these actions.

label: safe

text: To get that list of domains that the malware will use, defenders have to decode the algorithm which can be difficult.

text: The vulnerability affects the Toast feature on Android devices, an Android feature that allows display messages and notifications of other applications to “pop up,” and allows an attacker to employ an overlay attack.

tokenize_text: vulnerability affect toast feature android device android feature allows display message notification application pop allows attacker employ overlay attack

text: An overlay attack happens when an attacker places a window over a legitimate application on the device.
label: safe
tokenize_text: overlay attack happens attacker place window legitimate application device

text: Users will interact with the window, thinking they are performing their intended function, but they are actually engaging with the attackers overlay window and executing the attacker’s desired function.

text: Figure 1: Bogus patch installer overlying malware requesting administrative permissions  This interaction can install malware or malicious software on the device, grant malware full administrative privileges or lock the user out and render the device unusable.  In the past successful overlay attacks were typically dependent on two conditions:  However, with this particular vulnerability, these conditions are no longer required for a successful attack.

text: If you need to understand one thing about cybercrime, it’s that it is all about business.

text: In our latest Unit 42 research on cybercriminals using the Hancitor malware, we show that not only are their attacks about business, we can see these cybercriminals deftly applying some fundamental business principles around timing, specialization, and globalization.
label: identity
tokenize_text: latest unit research cybercriminals using hancitor malware show attack business see cybercriminals deftly applying fundamental business principle around timing specialization globalization

text: Hancitor is a malware that focuses getting other malware onto the victim’s system.

text: In the case of Hancitor, it’s typically banking Trojans that steal the victim’s banking information.
label: malware
tokenize_text: case hancitor typically banking trojan steal victim banking information

text: In our latest research, we can see the attackers behind Hancitor have been timing their attacks to happen during the busiest time of the global working week, the middle of the week.
label: malware
tokenize_text: latest research see attacker behind hancitor timing attack happen busiest time global working week middle week

text: And we’ve seen that in adapting their attacks to better evade detection, they’ve specialized their operations around the globe.
label: safe
tokenize_text: weve seen adapting attack better evade detection theyve specialized operation around globe

text: Hancitor isn’t particularly advanced in its tactics: it’s ideal target is an old or outdated version of Microsoft Windows like Windows 7 or even Windows XP.
label: malware
tokenize_text: hancitor isnt particularly advanced tactic ideal target old outdated version microsoft window like window even window xp

text: But it’s effective enough that when used in several hundred different spam campaigns every month it pays for the criminals to keep up these attacks against targets around the world.
label: safe
tokenize_text: effective enough used several hundred different spam campaign every month pay criminal keep attack target around world

text: Timing   In our most recent research, one of the things that jumped out for our researchers is the clear pattern around the timing of the attacks.
label: safe
tokenize_text: timing recent research one thing jumped researcher clear pattern around timing attack

text: As you can see in Figure 1 below, throughout 2017, the Hancitor attacks show clear spikes in their occurrence and these spikes happen during the middle of the week.
label: TIME

text: Figure 1: Timeline of Hancitor campaign activity since January 2017.
label: malware
tokenize_text: figure timeline hancitor campaign activity since january

text: The attackers behind Hancitor aren’t the first to time their spam attacks like this, but it is an effective tactic to try and increase their chances of success, especially when combined with the other innovation that we’ve seen.
label: malware
tokenize_text: attacker behind hancitor arent first time spam attack like effective tactic try increase chance success especially combined innovation weve seen

text: Adapting the Attacks
label: safe
tokenize_text: adapting attack

text: In the past, Hancitor was sent as a malicious attachment in a spam email which would then download and install the attackers’ final malware like a banking Trojan.
label: malware
tokenize_text: past hancitor sent malicious attachment spam email would download install attacker final malware like banking trojan

text: When they would do this, the Hancitor attachment would download and install the final malware from a malicious or compromised site.
label: malware
tokenize_text: would hancitor attachment would download install final malware malicious compromised site

text: But as organizations have gotten more effective at blocking malicious attachments like Hancitor, we’ve seen the attackers behind Hancitor adapt to evade detection and prevention.
label: malware
tokenize_text: organization gotten effective blocking malicious attachment like hancitor weve seen attacker behind hancitor adapt evade detection prevention

text: They’ve done this by moving the Hancitor malware from being a malicious attachment in spam to itself being a malicious download.
label: malware
tokenize_text: theyve done moving hancitor malware malicious attachment spam malicious download

text: The spam the attackers use no long has a malicious attachment but instead a malicious link that downloads the malicious Hancitor attachment.
label: malware
tokenize_text: spam attacker use long malicious attachment instead malicious link downloads malicious hancitor attachment

text: To do this, they make the spam look like something that requires you to click and download something like and invoice, a message, or a delivery notification.
label: safe
tokenize_text: make spam look like something requires click download something like invoice message delivery notification

text: Figure 2 shows one of these that was made to look like an Amazon shipping notice.
label: identity
tokenize_text: figure show one made look like amazon shipping notice

text: Figure 2: Hancitor malspam example from February 2017.
label: malware
tokenize_text: figure hancitor malspam example february

text: This means that a Hancitor attack now has two downloads rather than one and what these attackers did around the malicious downloads shows another modern business tactic: globalization.
label: malware
tokenize_text: mean hancitor attack two downloads rather one attacker around malicious downloads show another modern business tactic globalization

label: malware
tokenize_text: figure hancitor distribution server globally thus far table number distribution server country

text: The hot spots in the United States represents distribution servers which are created using fraud based accounts at various hosting providers that are hosting the Hancitor documents while the hotspots in Asia represent legitimate sites for small and medium businesses that have been compromised by the actors behind Hancitor campaign to host the malicious Hancitor documents.
label: malware
tokenize_text: hot spot united state represents distribution server created using fraud based account various hosting provider hosting hancitor document hotspot asia represent legitimate site small medium business compromised actor behind hancitor campaign host malicious hancitor document

text: Conclusion  Attackers are always making business decisions to optimize their attacks in ways that are most successful and profitable.
label: safe
tokenize_text: conclusion attacker always making business decision optimize attack way successful profitable

text: What is most interesting about Hancitor is the way these decisions so clearly reflect an awareness of business realities (by targeting peak working times) and dividing up the “work” of their attacks in a way that so clearly mirrors mainstream business decisions around globalizing operations.
label: malware
tokenize_text: interesting hancitor way decision clearly reflect awareness business reality targeting peak working time dividing work attack way clearly mirror mainstream business decision around globalizing operation

text: In the end, while Hancitor may not be sophisticated, these steps to adapt and stay effective seem to be succeeding.

text: And we expect to continue to see Hancitor be a global threat for the foreseeable future.
label: malware

text: Privilege escalation attacks against the kernel have been around for some time and are well-known and can be well protected against.  Kernel APC attacks however are a different class of attack.

text: APCs can basically be thought of as places in line for the CPU that the kernel gives access to.

text: But before we get into the details, here is a quick overview of mutexes and why they exist in the first place.

text: The mutex is the fundamental tool for managing shared resources between multiple threads (or processes).

text: If you think of the threads as a whole bunch of people in a meeting, all trying to talk at once, a mutex is the baton that gets passed from one person to the next so that there’s only one person talking at a time.

text: The important thing to understand is what the mutex is really protecting.

text: Here’s a more technical example.

text: Lets say you want to update an Internet Explorer (IE) cookie file, adding a unique identifier for use later.

text: Naively, what you need to do is read the cookie file in, add your data to what you’ve read, and write the file back to disk.

text: But what if IE is running and also updating that file?

text: The worst case, for you, is that both you and IE read the file at the same time but you write your edits first.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This is because IE will completely destroy your edits when it writes its new version of the file over yours.

text: The solution to this problem is to use a mutex to protect the integrity of the cookie file.

text: A process that has the mutex knows that while it holds that mutex no other process will be accessing the cookie file.

text: It can then read, tweak, and write the file without fear of any clobbering by other processes.

text: The following line of code attempts to validate the inbound password reset request by comparing the reset code submitted within the HTTP request with the reset code generated by OctoberCMS during a legitimate reset process:  To exploit this vulnerability, the actor would simply supply a boolean true value as the reset code within a custom-crafted HTTP request to reset the password of an account.

text: This effectively validates the actor’s inbound password reset request, which allows the actor to then change the password  To fix this vulnerability in version 1.0.472, the OctoberCMS developer changed the line of code above to use === instead of == when comparing the values of the reset code provided by the user via an HTTP POST request.

text: Following a recent study of apps in the Google Play Store, let’s discuss several security risks caused by the bad certificate management practiced in many Android apps, from social to mobile banking.

text: All Android apps must be digitally signed with a certificate from the developer.

text: As described in Google’s official document, the app developer is required to create a keystore with a set of private keys, and then use the private key to generate a signed version of apps.

label: SOFTWARE

text: DTLS is used by Microsoft Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) to provide communications privacy for datagram protocols.

text: The DTLS protocol is used by Microsoft Windows Remote Desktop Gateway (RDG) to establish a secure channel between the RDG client and RDG server (described in detail in [MS_TSGU].pdf).  The RDG client initiates the DTLS connection by sending a ClientHello to the RDG Server.  The RDG server then responds with a DTLS Hello Verify Request that contains a cookie; this is used as a denial of service countermeasure.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The RDG client responds once again with a Client Hello packet containing the received cookie, which will initiate the DTLS handshake (RFC6347 Section 4.2).   Figure 1: Initiation of the DTLS handshake between RDG client and server  Figure 2: RDG client and server handshake phase (Source: [MS-TSGU] Section 1.3.3.1.1)

text: When a client sends the DTLS ClientHello packet to the server, the server computes a Message Authentication Code (MAC) on it and compares it to the cookie contained in the packet.
label: safe
tokenize_text: client sends dtls clienthello packet server server computes message authentication code mac compare cookie contained packet

text: But the server only checks the cookie length field, not whether the cookie buffer can be read.
label: safe
tokenize_text: server check cookie length field whether cookie buffer read

text: In fact, a 32 byte length is always read, which could lead to a buffer out-of-bounds condition.
label: safe
tokenize_text: fact byte length always read could lead buffer outofbounds condition

text: It should be noted that a client could send a crafted packet to the server without needing to start an RDP session.
label: safe
tokenize_text: noted client could send crafted packet server without needing start rdp session

text: Figure 3, below, shows a packet crafted to display a “Cookie Length” of 32 (32 is equivalent to 0x20 in hexadecimal), which does not match the actual amount of data in the cookie (shown containing only two 0x41 characters).
label: safe
tokenize_text: figure show packet crafted display cookie length equivalent x hexadecimal match actual amount data cookie shown containing two x character

text: Figure 3: A crafted packet sending mismatched size and content  Related code is found in the DTLSCookieManager::ValidateCookie function:  As shown above, although the server checks the “CookieSize” field, the compared length is always *(_DWORD *)(mgr + 16)), whose value is 0x20; however, the real cookie buffer length could be less than 0x20.
label: safe
tokenize_text: figure crafted packet sending mismatched size content related code found dtlscookiemanagervalidatecookie function shown although server check cookiesize field compared length always _dword mgr whose value x however real cookie buffer length could le x

text: A crafted packet could set the “CookieSize” field to 0x20 and have the actual cookie buffer contain less than 0x20 bytes of data.  When a DTLS client receives a HelloVerifyRequest packet with a CookieSize larger than 32 bytes the client does not properly validate the CookieSize value against the amount of cookie data in the packet.
label: safe

text: Table 1. Ransomware sample comparison summary.

text: While there is a lot of overlap between HelloXD and Babuk, there are some small but crucial differences to take note of between Babuk and the two different variants.  HelloXD version 1 is the least modified, utilizing Curve25519-Donna and a modified HC-128 algorithm to encrypt file data, while also containing the same CRC hashing routine incorporating the string dong, possibly referencing Chuong Dong, who had previously analyzed and reported on the first version of Babuk (Figure 8).
label: malware
tokenize_text: lot overlap helloxd babuk small crucial difference take note babuk two different variant helloxd version least modified utilizing curvedonna modified hc algorithm encrypt file data also containing crc hashing routine incorporating string dong possibly referencing chuong dong previously analyzed reported first version babuk figure

text: The HelloXD author(s) did modify the infamous file marker and mutex however, opting for dxunmgqehhehyrhtxywuhwrvzxqrcblo as the file marker and With best wishes And good intentions… as the mutex (Figure 9).
label: malware
tokenize_text: helloxd author modify infamous file marker mutex however opting dxunmgqehhehyrhtxywuhwrvzxqrcblo file marker best wish good intention mutex figure

text: With HelloXD version 2, the author(s) opted to alter the encryption routine, swapping out the modified HC-128 algorithm with the Rabbit symmetric cipher.
label: malware
tokenize_text: helloxd version author opted alter encryption routine swapping modified hc algorithm rabbit symmetric cipher

text: Additionally, the file marker changed again, this time to what seems to be random bytes rather than a coherent string.
label: safe
tokenize_text: additionally file marker changed time seems random byte rather coherent string

text: The mutex is also modified, set to nqldslhumipyuzjnatqucmuycqkxjon in one of the samples (Figure 10).
label: safe
tokenize_text: mutex also modified set nqldslhumipyuzjnatqucmuycqkxjon one sample figure

text: Both versions have been compiled with the same compiler (believed to be GCC 3.x and above based on the mangling of export names), resulting in very similar exports between not only the ransomware variants, but also other malware that we have linked to the potential author (Figure 11).  The biggest difference between the versions is the interesting addition of a secondary payload embedded within version 2.
label: SOFTWARE
tokenize_text: version compiled compiler believed gcc x based mangling export name resulting similar export ransomware variant also malware linked potential author figure biggest difference version interesting addition secondary payload embedded within version

text: This payload is encrypted using the WinCrypt API, in the same fashion as the obfuscated loader discussed above.
label: safe
tokenize_text: payload encrypted using wincrypt api fashion obfuscated loader discussed

text: Once decrypted, the payload is dropped to System32 with the name userlogin.exe before a service is created that points to it.
label: FILEPATH
tokenize_text: decrypted payload dropped system name userloginexe service created point

text: userlogin.exe is then executed (Figure 12).
label: safe
tokenize_text: userloginexe executed figure

text: What is peculiar about this file is it is a variant of the open-source MicroBackdoor, a backdoor allowing an attacker to browse the file system, upload and download files, execute commands and remove itself from the system (Figure 13).
label: malware
tokenize_text: peculiar file variant opensource microbackdoor backdoor allowing attacker browse file system upload download file execute command remove system figure

text: As the threat actor would normally have a foothold into the network prior to ransomware deployment, it raises the question of why this backdoor is part of the ransomware execution.
label: safe
tokenize_text: threat actor would normally foothold network prior ransomware deployment raise question backdoor part ransomware execution

text: One possibility is that it is used to monitor ransomed systems for blue team and incident response (IR) activity, though even in that case it is unusual to see offensive tools dropped at this point in the infection.
label: safe
tokenize_text: one possibility used monitor ransomed system blue team incident response ir activity though even case unusual see offensive tool dropped point infection

text: While analyzing the ransomware binaries, we discovered a unique string prevalent in almost all of the samples: :wtfbbq (stored as UTF-16LE).
label: safe
tokenize_text: analyzing ransomware binary discovered unique string prevalent almost sample wtfbbq stored utfle

text: Querying VirusTotal with this string led to the discovery of eight files, six of which could be directly attributed to x4k through their own VirusTotal graph mapping out their infrastructure.
label: SOFTWARE
tokenize_text: querying virustotal string led discovery eight file six could directly attributed xk virustotal graph mapping infrastructure

text: The discovered samples are primarily Cobalt Strike Beacons, utilizing heavy control flow obfuscation – unlike the HelloXD ransomware samples we had previously seen.
label: tools
tokenize_text: discovered sample primarily cobalt strike beacon utilizing heavy control flow obfuscation unlike helloxd ransomware sample previously seen

text: Unfortunately, this specific string is not completely unique to x4k, and is instead found on several GitHub repositories as part of a technique to allow a running executable to delete itself from disk through renaming primary data streams within the file to :wtfbbq.
label: threat-actor

text: Running a search for the non-UTF-16LE string results in multiple files, and filtering for executables yields 10 results, the majority of which are NIM-based binaries – potentially linked to this GitHub repository.

text: While the :wtfbbq string is not unique to x4k, by searching for the UTF-16LE version found inside the analyzed HelloXD ransomware samples, we only came across binaries linked to x4k’s infrastructure, providing a fairly strong link between HelloXD and x4k.

text: On May 27, 2022, details began to emerge of malicious Word documents leveraging remote templates to execute PowerShell via the ms-msdt Office URL protocol.

text: Due to the amount of publicly available information, ease of use, and the extreme effectiveness of this exploit, Palo Alto Networks is providing this threat brief to make our customers aware of this critical vulnerability and the options available to ensure proper protections are put into place until a patch can be issued by Microsoft.  The vulnerability enables remote code execution with the same privileges as the calling application and there are proof-of-concept examples of zero-click variants.

Attack Details for CVE-2022-30190 CVE-2022-30190 in the Wild Conclusion  On May 27, 2022, a cybersecurity research team out of Tokyo, Japan, nao_sec, uncovered a malicious Word document uploaded to VirusTotal from an IP in Belarus.

text: The HTML code from the remote template is shown in Figure 1 below.

text: The JavaScript embedded within the HTML uses the ms-msdt schema to invoke the PCWDiagnostic pack, to reference the IT_BrowseForFile to execute the base64-encoded PowerShell Invoke-Expression command.  The base64-decoded text within the PowerShell Invoke-Expression is shown in Figure 2 below.
label: tools

text: Earth Baku deploys its ongoing campaign, which can be traced to as far back as July 2020, through multiple attack vectors that are designed based on different exploits or the infrastructure of its targeted victim's environment:  • SQL injection to upload a malicious file • Installment through InstallUtil.exe in a scheduled task • Possibly a malicious link (LNK) file sent as an email attachment • Exploitation of the ProxyLogon vulnerability CVE-2021-26855 to upload a China Chopper web shell  This campaign uses previously unidentified shellcode loaders, which we have named StealthVector and StealthMutant, and a backdoor, which we have dubbed ScrambleCross.

text: Most of these actors use the same methods of access found in many ransomware attacks, such as phishing emails and exploiting unprotected internet-facing applications, the lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA), as well as the typical avenues used to preserve and enhance access once it’s achieved, such as through the use of Cobalt Strike or PowerShell.

text: When using double extortion, attackers will not only lock up a victim’s files and demand ransom, but they will also steal files and threaten to publish them on a website or otherwise leak them if their initial ransom demand is not met.  But Conti’s methods do have atypical elements.

text: Unit 42 researchers have been following the Shamoon 2 attacks closely since November 2016.

tokenize_text: unit researcher following shamoon attack closely since november

text: To date, Shamoon 2 has unfolded in three separate attack waves on November 11, 2016, November 29, 2016, and January 23, 2017.

text: Based on our newest research, we can answer a question that many have had about these attacks: how is Shamoon 2 able to enter an organization’s network and spread so widely?
label: threat-actor

text: The answer is simple: credential theft.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: answer simple credential theft

text: Credential theft has been known to be a key part of the Shamoon 2 attacks.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: credential theft known key part shamoon attack

text: What our research is showing that’s new is how the attackers use the credentials once they’ve breached the network.
label: safe
tokenize_text: research showing thats new attacker use credential theyve breached network

text: And from this we can see how credential theft is the keystone of Shamoon 2 attacks; if an organization can prevent credential theft, the Shamoon 2 attacks can’t succeed.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: see credential theft keystone shamoon attack organization prevent credential theft shamoon attack cant succeed

text: In our research, we’re able to outline that Shamoon 2 enters and spreads through an organization in three stages:  These stages are outlined in the image below.  And that credential theft is a key element in each stage:  It’s also worth noting that credentials are a keystone issue in Shamoon 2 wave 2 too: we saw evidence of targeting an organization’s virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) solutions with default credentials.
label: threat-actor
tokenize_text: research able outline shamoon enters spread organization three stage stage outlined image credential theft key element stage also worth noting credential keystone issue shamoon wave saw evidence targeting organization virtual desktop infrastructure vdi solution default credential

text: This is also suggestive of access to the network through legitimate, stolen credentials.

text: This also helps to set context for how widely Disttrack can attempt to spread: 844 systems, each attempting to spread to 256, means that from one distribution server, Shamoon 2 attackers could potentially try to spread Disttrack to 216,064 systems; and that’s not counting if any of those infected systems, in turn, attempts to spread to an additional 256 systems.

text: Vulnerability Details  CVE-2014-6271 exists in all versions of Bash and is related to how environment variables are processed when the shell starts up.

text: Environment variables are used by shell software to store pieces of information like the location of the user’s home directory.

text: In addition to storing variables, Bash allows for storing shell functions in variables that users can call later.

text: It’s in parsing these functions that the new Bash vulnerability exists, as the shell mistakenly executes code that is added after a function definition.

text: These reports indicate that in addition to the internal lateral movement already outlined, the WanaCrypt0r ransomware will scan for port 445 on random external IP addresses and if it finds an IP address with an open port 445, it will then scan all devices on the same /24 IP range (i.e. that share the first three octets as that IP address with the open port 445).  In general, WanaCrypt0r does not have C2 capabilities but it does utilize the TOR network to communicate encryption keys for decryption upon payment of ransom.

text: Command  Behavior  Compress_Files  Compresses specified files or directories to a ZIP archive  Decompress_File  Extracts files from a specified ZIP archive  AutoRun  Creates a scheduled task for persistence  CloseEverything  Kills the Everything process with the command “TASKKILL /F /IM Everything.exe”  OpenEverything  Downloads and runs Everything from voidtools  CloseFFmpegLive  Kills the FFmpeg process with the command “TASKKILL /F /IM ffmpeg.exe”  OpenFFmpegLive  Downloads and runs FFmpeg (for screen video capture)  DeleteFile  Deletes files or directories at specified locations  CreateDir  Creates a directory at a specified location  ShowFiles  Gets the disk partition or lists a specified directory with detailed information, including file name, file path, size, create time, and time of modification  Download_File  Downloads a URL and saves the file to a specified location  Upload_File  Uploads the victim’s files to cloud storage  uUninstall  Kills the BIOPASS RAT process and deletes installed files.  CloseObsLive  Kills the OBS process with command “TASKKILL /F /IM obs64.exe”  Open_Obs_Live  Downloads OBS Studio and starts live streaming  ProcessList  Lists processes on the victim’s environment and their process identifier (PID)  KillProcess  Kills the process specified by PID with the TASKKILL command  ScreenShot  Takes a screenshot and uploads it to cloud storage  Shell  Executes commands or scripts (subcommands with prefixes subprocess, python, noreturn, getversion, restart)  SnsInfo  Lists QQ, WeChat, and Aliwangwang directories  InstallTcpdump  Downloads and installs the tcpdump tool  PackingTelegram  Compresses and uploads Telegram's “tdata” directory to cloud storage  CloseProxy  Kills frpc process with command “TASKKILL /F /IM frpc.exe”  OpenProxy  Downloads and installs the frp proxy client in the “%PUBLIC%” folder  OpenVnc  Downloads and installs jsmpeg-vnc tool in the “%PUBLIC%/vnc/” folder  CloseVnc  Kills the VNC process with the command “TASKKILL /F /IM vdwm.exe”  GetBrowsersCookies  Decrypts the cookie file of the browser and uploads it to cloud storage  GetBrowsersLogins  Decrypts the login file of the browser and uploads it to cloud storage  GetBrowsersHistories  Uploads the history file of the browser to cloud storage  GetBrowsersBookmarks  Uploads the bookmark file of the browser to cloud storage   Table 2.

tokenize_text: found several connection biopass rat winnti group

text: 1.      We discovered that many BIOPASS RAT loader binaries were signed with two valid certificates.
label: malware
tokenize_text: discovered many biopass rat loader binary signed two valid certificate

text: It is well known that the Winnti Group has previously used stolen certificates from game studios to sign its malware.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: well known winnti group previously used stolen certificate game studio sign malware

text: Certificate Thumbprint  Valid From  Valid To  EFB70718BC00393A01694F255A28E30E9D2142A4  12:00 a.m.,  Jan. 2, 2019  11:59 p.m., Mar. 2, 2021  8CE020AA874902C532B9911A4DCA8EFFA627DC80  12:00 a.m., Sept. 6, 2018  11:59 p.m., Oct. 5, 2021   Table 3.
label: TIME
tokenize_text: certificate thumbprint valid valid efbbcafaeeda jan pm mar ceaacbadcaeffadc sept pm oct table

text: Information from the stolen certificates   2.      While checking the stolen certificates, we found a server-side variant of the Derusbi malware sample (e5fdb754c1a7c36c288c46765c9258bb2c7f38fa2a99188a623182f877da3783) that was signed with the same stolen certificate.
label: SHA2
tokenize_text: information stolen certificate checking stolen certificate found serverside variant derusbi malware sample efdbcaccccbbcffaaafda signed stolen certificate

text: Derusbi is known to be used by multiple advanced persistent threat (APT) groups.
label: malware
tokenize_text: derusbi known used multiple advanced persistent threat apt group

text: The server-side variant has also been noted to be used as a malware loader by the Winnti Group.
label: threat-actor
tokenize_text: serverside variant also noted used malware loader winnti group

text: 3.      We found an interesting Cobalt Strike loader (a7e9e2bec3ad283a9a0b130034e822c8b6dfd26dda855f883a3a4ff785514f97) that embeds a URL that leads to the BIOPASS RAT loader.
label: SHA2
tokenize_text: found interesting cobalt strike loader aeebecadaabecbdfdddafaafff embeds url lead biopass rat loader

text: However, the URL is unused and was likely left inside the loader as a mistake.
label: safe
tokenize_text: however url unused likely left inside loader mistake

text: The Cobalt Strike loader, which has a PDB string “C:\Users\test\Desktop\fishmaster\x64\Release\fishmaster.pdb”, connects to the C&C server “download[.]google-images[.]ml”.
label: tools
tokenize_text: cobalt strike loader pdb string cuserstestdesktopfishmasterxreleasefishmasterpdb connects cc server downloadgoogleimagesml

text: The domains and the PDB string have been mentioned in a recent report and have been attributed to the Winnti Group.
label: threat-actor
tokenize_text: domain pdb string mentioned recent report attributed winnti group

text: While these connections allow us to link the malware to the Winnti Group, the different targets between BIOPASS RAT and the current operations by Winnti’s that we are tracking makes associating the two more difficult.
label: threat-actor
tokenize_text: connection allow u link malware winnti group different target biopass rat current operation winntis tracking make associating two difficult

text: BIOPASS RAT highlights the importance of downloading from trusted sources BIOPASS RAT is a sophisticated type of malware that is implemented as Python scripts.
label: malware
tokenize_text: biopass rat highlight importance downloading trusted source biopass rat sophisticated type malware implemented python script

text: It possesses many features, such as the ability to use scheduled tasks as a method of maintaining persistence in the infected system.
label: safe
tokenize_text: posse many feature ability use scheduled task method maintaining persistence infected system

text: The malware abuses publicly available tools and cloud services for its malicious behavior.
label: safe
tokenize_text: malware abuse publicly available tool cloud service malicious behavior

text: Given that the malware loader was delivered as an executable disguised as a legitimate update installer on a compromised website, we advise users to be careful  with regard to the applications that they download.
label: safe
tokenize_text: given malware loader delivered executable disguised legitimate update installer compromised website advise user careful regard application download

text: As much as possible, it is recommended to download apps only from trusted sources and official websites to avoid being compromised by attacks such as the one discussed here.
label: safe
tokenize_text: much possible recommended download apps trusted source official website avoid compromised attack one discussed

text: Organizations can also help protect their end users by implementing security solutions that provide  a multilayered defense system that helps with detecting, scanning, and blocking malicious URLs.
label: safe
tokenize_text: organization also help protect end user implementing security solution provide multilayered defense system help detecting scanning blocking malicious url

text: Note that we’ve submitted an abuse report to Alibaba, but we have yet to receive feedback at the time of publication.
label: identity
tokenize_text: note weve submitted abuse report alibaba yet receive feedback time publication

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  On May 4, 2022, F5 released a security advisory for a remote code execution vulnerability in the iControlREST component of its BIG-IP product tracked in CVE-2022-1388.

text: Blackgear (also known as Topgear and Comnie) is a cyberespionage campaign dating back to 2008, at least based on the Protux backdoor used by its operators.
label: campaign
tokenize_text: blackgear also known topgear comnie cyberespionage campaign dating back least based protux backdoor used operator

text: In 2016, for instance, we found their campaigns attacking Japanese organizations with various malware tools, notably the Elirks backdoor.
label: TIME
tokenize_text: instance found campaign attacking japanese organization various malware tool notably elirks backdoor

text: Blackgear’s operators are well-organized, developing their own tools, which we observed to have been recently fine-tuned, based on their latest attacks.
label: threat-actor
tokenize_text: blackgears operator wellorganized developing tool observed recently finetuned based latest attack

text: A notable characteristic of Blackgear is the degree to which its attacks are taken to evade detection, abusing blogging, microblogging, and social media services to hide its command-and-control (C&C) configuration.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: notable characteristic blackgear degree attack taken evade detection abusing blogging microblogging social medium service hide commandandcontrol cc configuration

text: Compared to when C&C information is embedded within the malware, where it’s preset and can thus be easily blocked, this tactic lets Blackgear’s operators to quickly change C&C servers as needed.
label: threat-actor
tokenize_text: compared cc information embedded within malware preset thus easily blocked tactic let blackgears operator quickly change cc server needed

text: It can, in turn, prolong the campaign’s foothold in the system and enable attackers to carry out further lateral movement.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: turn prolong campaign foothold system enable attacker carry lateral movement

text: Analyzing the Marade downloader (detected by Trend Micro as TSPY_MARADE.ZTBC) and the version of Protux (BKDR_PROTUX.ZTBC) employed by Blackgear’s latest campaigns, we found their encrypted configurations on blog and social media posts (see Figure 1).

text: Here’s a summary of Blackgear’s latest campaign:  Use a decoy document or fake installer file, sent via spam email to lure a potential victim into clicking it.

label: safe

text: Marade will check if the infected host can connect to the internet and if it is installed with anti-virus (AV) software.

text: If the affected system can connect online and doesn’t have AV software, Marade will connect to a Blackgear-controlled public blog or social media post to retrieve an encrypted C&C configuration.

text: Otherwise, Marade will use the C&C information embedded in its code.

Blackgear’s malware tools are delivered to targets using RAR self-extracting executable (SFX) files or office Visual Basic Script (VBScript) to create a decoy document.

text: Standard phishing attacks are broad attacks that use general email messages to carry out the attacks.

text: Standard phishing attacks aren’t personalized: they use very common themes or lures in a generalized way in conjunction with a large enough pool of targets.

tokenize_text: standard phishing attack arent personalized use common theme lure generalized way conjunction large enough pool target

text: The idea is that by chance some percentage of the phishing emails will look legitimate enough to the recipient to be successful.

text: Basically, standard phishing attacks rely on the law of averages for its success.

text: Spear phishing is a more refined and focused version of phishing.

text: Instead of using generalized themes or lures, spear phishing uses themes or lures that are in some way relevant or appropriate for the target recipient.

text: For example, a spear phishing attack could use email messages about military exercises sent to military or government targets like we saw with our recent research into CMSTAR Trojan attacks.

text: In early September 2021, Threat Analysis Group (TAG) observed a financially motivated threat actor we refer to as EXOTIC LILY, exploiting a 0day in Microsoft MSHTML (CVE-2021-40444).

text: Investigating this group's activity, we determined they are an Initial Access Broker (IAB) who appear to be working with the Russian cyber crime gang known as FIN12 (Mandiant, FireEye) / WIZARD SPIDER (CrowdStrike).

text: In 2016, the group set up aggressive credential phishing attacks against the Democratic National Convention (DNC), German political party Christian Democratic Union (CDU), the parliament and government of Turkey, the parliament of Montenegro, the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), Al Jazeera, and many other organizations.

text: If communication with C&C fails, and if the PowerShell script is run from a command line, a few error messages written in simplified Mandarin Chinese are displayed, with a curious phrase that translates to "waiting for dragon":  无法访问本地计算机寄存器 (Unable to access local computer register) 任务计划程序访问被拒绝 (Mission Scheduler access is denied) 无法连接到网址，请等待龙 (Cannot connect to URL, please wait for dragon) 无法连接到网址，请等待龙 (Cannot connect to website, please wait for dragon)  These messages may not reveal anything about the real attackers as the malware writers sometimes like to embed false flags into their programs to confuse researchers.
label: location

text: Countermeasures and Trend Micro Solutions Users unfamiliar with the various kinds of social engineering techniques might find it difficult to distinguish a legitimate message from a malicious one – thus the need for education on identifying and mitigating phishing attacks – especially if it involves organizations in sensitive industries such as government and manufacturing.

text: Method B: Self modifying the APK  This exploit can take advantage of the same vulnerability to mask what permissions the app really requires.  This vulnerability affects Android device users as well as Android app developers.  For Android device users, the users may end up with installing apps that are not the ones they agree to install.  Android app developers are also affected, because app-store apps and mobile ads libraries that do not rely on Google Play store would be likely to save the promoted apps in unprotected storage, e.g. /sdcard.

text: Since late 2019, our team has disrupted financially motivated phishing campaigns targeting YouTubers with Cookie Theft malware.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: since late team disrupted financially motivated phishing campaign targeting youtubers cookie theft malware

text: The actors behind this campaign, which we attribute to a group of hackers recruited in a Russian-speaking forum, lure their target with fake collaboration opportunities (typically a demo for anti-virus software, VPN, music players, photo editing or online games), hijack their channel, then either sell it to the highest bidder or use it to broadcast cryptocurrency scams.
label: location
tokenize_text: actor behind campaign attribute group hacker recruited russianspeaking forum lure target fake collaboration opportunity typically demo antivirus software vpn music player photo editing online game hijack channel either sell highest bidder use broadcast cryptocurrency scam

text: In collaboration with YouTube, Gmail, Trust & Safety, CyberCrime Investigation Group and Safe Browsing teams, our protections have decreased the volume of related phishing emails on Gmail by 99.6% since May 2021.
label: location
tokenize_text: collaboration youtube gmail trust safety cybercrime investigation group safe browsing team protection decreased volume related phishing email gmail since may

text: We blocked 1.6M messages to targets, displayed ~62K Safe Browsing phishing page warnings, blocked 2.4K files, and successfully restored ~4K accounts.
label: location
tokenize_text: blocked message target displayed k safe browsing phishing page warning blocked k file successfully restored k account

text: Additional analysis and insights by Higashi Yuka and Chizuru Toyama REDBALDKNIGHT, also known as BRONZE BUTLER and Tick, is a cyberespionage group known to target Japanese organizations such as government agencies (including defense) as well as those in biotechnology, electronics manufacturing, and industrial chemistry.

text: However, since threat actors tend to cover their tracks quickly, by the time the security analyst is reviewing the incident, there is a chance that critical information may have been permanently deleted and is no longer readily accessible.          Instead of depending on a security analyst to review a credential dumping event and manually collecting artifacts for their investigation, Trend Micro wanted to automate the collection of this evidence as quickly as possible when a detection occurs.

text: Since late 2019, our team has disrupted financially motivated phishing campaigns targeting YouTubers with Cookie Theft malware.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: since late team disrupted financially motivated phishing campaign targeting youtubers cookie theft malware

text: The actors behind this campaign, which we attribute to a group of hackers recruited in a Russian-speaking forum, lure their target with fake collaboration opportunities (typically a demo for anti-virus software, VPN, music players, photo editing or online games), hijack their channel, then either sell it to the highest bidder or use it to broadcast cryptocurrency scams.
label: location
tokenize_text: actor behind campaign attribute group hacker recruited russianspeaking forum lure target fake collaboration opportunity typically demo antivirus software vpn music player photo editing online game hijack channel either sell highest bidder use broadcast cryptocurrency scam

text: In collaboration with YouTube, Gmail, Trust & Safety, CyberCrime Investigation Group and Safe Browsing teams, our protections have decreased the volume of related phishing emails on Gmail by 99.6% since May 2021.
label: location
tokenize_text: collaboration youtube gmail trust safety cybercrime investigation group safe browsing team protection decreased volume related phishing email gmail since may

text: We blocked 1.6M messages to targets, displayed ~62K Safe Browsing phishing page warnings, blocked 2.4K files, and successfully restored ~4K accounts.
label: location
tokenize_text: blocked message target displayed k safe browsing phishing page warning blocked k file successfully restored k account

text: Cookie Theft, also known as “pass-the-cookie attack,” is a session hijacking technique that enables access to user accounts with session cookies stored in the browser.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: cookie theft also known passthecookie attack session hijacking technique enables access user account session cooky stored browser

text: The phishing typically started with a customized email introducing the company and its products.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: phishing typically started customized email introducing company product

text: Once the target agreed to the deal, a malware landing page disguised as a software download URL was sent via email or a PDF on Google Drive, and in a few cases, Google documents containing the phishing links.
label: location
tokenize_text: target agreed deal malware landing page disguised software download url sent via email pdf google drive case google document containing phishing link

text: Because Google actively detects and disrupts phishing links sent via Gmail, the actors were observed driving targets to messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram or Discord.
label: location
tokenize_text: google actively detects disrupts phishing link sent via gmail actor observed driving target messaging apps like whatsapp telegram discord

text: Some commodity malware used included RedLine, Vidar, Predator The Thief, Nexus stealer, Azorult, Raccoon, Grand Stealer, Vikro Stealer, Masad (Google’s naming), and Kantal (Google’s naming) which shares code similarity with Vidar.
label: malware
tokenize_text: commodity malware used included redline vidar predator thief nexus stealer azorult raccoon grand stealer vikro stealer masad google naming kantal google naming share code similarity vidar

text: Open source malware like Sorano and AdamantiumThief were also observed.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: open source malware like sorano adamantiumthief also observed

label: location

text: In this blog, we explore some of the most notable campaigns we’ve disrupted this year from a different government-backed attacker: APT35, an Iranian group, which regularly conducts phishing campaigns targeting high risk users.
label: location
tokenize_text: blog explore notable campaign weve disrupted year different governmentbacked attacker apt iranian group regularly conduct phishing campaign targeting high risk user

text: In early 2021, APT35 compromised a website affiliated with a UK university to host a phishing kit.
label: threat-actor
tokenize_text: early apt compromised website affiliated uk university host phishing kit

text: The phishing kit will also ask for second-factor authentication codes sent to devices.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: phishing kit also ask secondfactor authentication code sent device

text: APT35 has relied on this technique since 2017 — targeting high-value accounts in government, academia, journalism, NGOs, foreign policy, and national security.
label: threat-actor
tokenize_text: apt relied technique since targeting highvalue account government academia journalism ngo foreign policy national security

text: Credential phishing through a compromised website demonstrates these attackers will go to great lengths to appear legitimate – as they know it's difficult for users to detect this kind of attack.
label: attack-pattern
tokenize_text: credential phishing compromised website demonstrates attacker go great length appear legitimate know difficult user detect kind attack

text: Tropic Trooper, a threat actor group that targets government, military, healthcare, transportation, and high-tech industries in Taiwan, the Philippines, and Hong Kong, has been active since 2011.
label: identity

text: The group was reportedly using spear-phishing emails with weaponized attachments to exploit known vulnerabilities.

text: We found that Tropic Trooper’s latest activities center on targeting Taiwanese and the Philippine military’s physically isolated networks through a USBferry attack (the name derived from a sample found in a related research).

text: Sharing cybersecurity knowledge to the private sector

text: Earth Baku deploys its ongoing campaign, which can be traced to as far back as July 2020, through multiple attack vectors that are designed based on different exploits or the infrastructure of its targeted victim's environment:  • SQL injection to upload a malicious file • Installment through InstallUtil.exe in a scheduled task • Possibly a malicious link (LNK) file sent as an email attachment • Exploitation of the ProxyLogon vulnerability CVE-2021-26855 to upload a China Chopper web shell  This campaign uses previously unidentified shellcode loaders, which we have named StealthVector and StealthMutant, and a backdoor, which we have dubbed ScrambleCross.
